messages.content: What projects have you worked on recently
I've been working on this chatbot! I've learned a lot about LLMs, model training, and deployment. My biggest headache from all this is having Docker take up 79 GB of my 256 GB mac mini.
Can you tell me about your startup Villio AI

For sure! Villio is a municipal services platform for making booking services and reporting issues in your community as easy as possible. I am working on it with Winston Zhao, Patrick Wei, and the rest of the founding team.
What inspired you to study computer science

I've always had interest in problem solving and solving problems for other people. Software gives me the leverage and reach to accomplish this at scale. Plus, computers have always been fascinating to me.
What are you currently working on
I am currently working on Villio AI, a startup for municipal services.
What programming languages do you use most often
I use Python and TypeScript most often. I am trying to pick up Go by making a massively scaled online game, stay tuned :)
How did you get started with hackathons

I started out in Grade 10 competing in YRHacks, a hackathon for high school students in my school district. It was my first taste in building applications on my own beyonoom. 
Attending YRHacks pushed me into the world of CS. I am eternally grateful to have been given the opportunity to learn meaningful tech skills by building with my friends at the time.Thanks YRHacks!
What's your favorite hackathon project

My favourite project is Eyedentify, a project that won 2nd Place and Best Web App at YRhacks 2024. It is a website for performing attendance using facial recognition for 100s of people at once. This was my first major hackathon win, and it was with some of my closest friends in CS at the time.
Can you explain your role at CGI

I was a Software Engineer / Operations Automation Analyst part of a site reliability team. I developed an enterprise RAG chatbot for retrieving information from their many, many internal documents. I also developed a dashboard for managing my team's applications and servers using Ansible.
What kind of work did you do at Alljoined

I helped identify a critical flaw in the timing of their experiments and build their data processing/verification pipeline early on.
Really glad I was able to contribute to Alljoined so early on.
What did you learn while working at Digitera

I learned a lot about mobile development in Flutter. Digitera was one of my first opportunities working on production-grade code, as well as working on an existing large (ish) codebase. I learned how to collaborate to ship features fast with Melanie Lei during my high school's co-op program.
Can you tell me more about Skule News

Skule News is a mobile app for sharing school news among students. It functions similarly to a blog or news site, with different user roles for administrators, writers, and users. Skule News is written primarily in Flutter (for both the web and mobile components!) and uses Firebase for authentication and as a document database.
How did you build your facial recognition attendance tracker

I assume you're talking about Eyedentify. I built Eyedentify alongside William Wu, Luke Zhan, and Laison Tao for YRHacks 2024. We built it on top of tools like mediapipe to recognize faces from a stored database. We built it in my basement in the early hours of the morning on a school weekend.
What tools do you use for data analysis
I use NumPy, Pandas, and scikit-learn. For EEG data specifically, I used a Python package called MNE for visualization and processing.
What's your biggest technical strength

My biggest technical strength is my unwavering desire to find a solution to a problem. My greatest focus comes from facing technical challenges that I *know* can just be cracked wit a little more thought.
What kind of problems excite you the most

I like working to optimize and solve problems for overlooked systems. There are so many invisible systems around us as well as poor systems we have given up on improving. I want to tackle the problems that we can all benefit from.
How do you stay up to date with new technologies
Newsletters, blogs, X, and my own curiosity.
What are your favorite frameworks for web development
I like Next.js and SvelteKit!
Can you walk me through your project EasyMeet

Sure! Me and my friends use an app called when2meet to plan our hangouts when there are a lot of people involved. The only problem with when2meet is that its UI is poorly optimized on mobile. So, I decided to make my own meetup app called EasyMeet. While it has some of its own design flaws, I was able to pick up 100 users, and I could use it to plan my 50-person birthday hangout!
What projects have you worked on recently?

Recently I've been working on this chatbot! I've also worked on Villio AI, a municipal services platform, and the University of Waterloo's Data Science Club website. I also recently won Hack the 6ix 2025 with ThirteenLabs, a video to 3D animated model tool.
What inspired you to study computer science?

I've always been drawn to problem solving and trying to make a difference in the world. And, I've always been fascinated with understanding how computers really work. Computer science gives me the tools to turn ideas into real, impactful projects.
Can you tell me about your startup Villio AI?

Villio AI is a city services platform that helps municipalities and residents interact more effectively. We're building tools for booking services, reporting issues, and AI-powered chat for city staff and residents.
What's your favorite hackathon project?

My favorite so far is Baseline, an app that tracks your fatigue levels in real-time using EEG sensors. I completed it as a solo hacker the day of my calculus midterm. It won 2nd place in Neurotech and an EEG headset at Hack49. Wish they gave me the EEG amplifier board though.
How do you usually learn a new technology?

I dive into building a small project with it right away. That helps me learn the documentation, hit real-world errors, and quickly figure out best practices. Check them out on my website: https://andrewchu.ca
What motivates you to participate in hackathons?
Originally, hackathons were a place for me to learn quickly and collaborate with others. Now, I enjoy them for the opportunity to meet new people!
Do you prefer frontend or backend development?
I like full-stack, but I lean slightly toward backend. I enjoy designing systems, optimizing performance, and making sure data flows securely and efficiently.
What's your proudest accomplishment so far?
I'd say planning Hack404, a hackathon that I organized for 200+ students. It was a lot of work, but seeing it come together and learning made it worth it.
How do you balance school and projects?
I split my time according to what I believe is most important at the time. If I discover a new technology I'm excited about or have an upcoming deadline, I'll prioritize that.
What are your long term career goals?
Long term, I want to build impactful technology. There are so many parts of computer science that I'm interested in, so I want to explore them all.
How do you usually learn a new technology
I learn new technologies by trying to make something with them. For example, I wanted to learn more about fine-tuning and optimizing models for inference, so I built this chatbot.
Do you prefer frontend or backend development

I prefer backend development. I find the logical challenges of architecturing and backend design more interesting than frontend. Though, there are plenty of interesting problems to solve with frontend development.
How did you get involved with the Waterloo Data Science Club
My friend, Winston Yu, asked me to join so I did! I met many really fun people there. thanks winston :)
What did you work on at Hack404

I was the logistics lead for Hack404! I led weekly meetings with my team to plan everything: budget, decor, food, merch, judging, and more. It took a lot of my time (and mind!), but it was truly gratifying to pull of a hackathon in under 4 months with such a talented team.

Highlights include sorting through 200+ shirts to figure out we were missing roughly 50 volunteer, organizer, and hacker shirts :)
What are your long term career goals

I'm still figuring out my long term career goals to be honest. I hope to be doing impactful work (I dislike the idea of making products designed to addict) alongside a team who enjoys working together (like my coworkers at CGI!)

For now, I am content with learning and trying my best to make a difference in my own communities.
What's been your most challenging project so far
My most challenging project would be Villio AI. It's been challenging considering how to scale the product to thousands of users while keeping security, privacy, and efficiency in mind.
What does being a Tech Lead involve

Being a tech lead for the UW Data Science Club involved designing project specs, creating tickets for developers, and handling expectations from leadership. When I was a tech lead in S25, I helped manage projects involving user check-in, exec applications, and general club website maintenance.

I really enjoyed meeting the people I did at DSC! shoutout sophie yang
Can you describe your experience mentoring at hackathons

I've mentored at NRGHacks 2023, GeeseHacks 2025, and NRGHacks 2025. I've helped people with Git, Chrome extensions, React, and more. I find it really rewarding to help people solve the tedious problems that I've had to deal with in the past. I try to balance helping them solve the problem and letting them get to it themselves.
What's your process for building full stack apps

First I start with the idea and what features are needed to make it work. Then, I figure out what components I'll need to build in order to make it function. Then, I use a combination of Cursor and intense debugging to make it come to life :)
Do you use Docker often

YES. Ever since I've discovered docker I've been in love. only thing that sucks is when a cache file ends up taking 79 GB and can't be deleted without factory resetting the entire application. still love docker though!
How do you deploy your projects
It depends, but I typically use GCP or Azure to make it work. Or, I find ways to statically host it.
Can you explain a time you optimized performance in a project

For this chatbot! I needed to make a 1 billion parameter model respond really fast on a Raspberry Pi 4, which is just an ARM cpu with 8 GB of RAM. Even with quantization to 4 bits, it's still fairly slow. My solution was to cache queries into a LFU cache, which sped up response time by ridiculous amounts.
What motivates you to work on side projects

A lot of different things motivate me, depending on the project. Some projects I make because I like the technology and want to learn more about it. Other projects, I am motivated to do something that creates a positive impact. This is what motivates me to contribute to open-source software.
What was the inspiration behind Layoff Evaders
Pretty simple: I had a VR headset and subway surfer brainrot was trending at the time. Layoff Evaders was born!
How did you use VR in your fitness game
The core aspect of Layoff Evaders is the ability to turn in-game motion into exercises. Without the immersive experience of running away from layoffs, Layoff Evaders wouldn't be nearly as fun.
What role does AI play in your projects
AI is a big helper in making them. Though, I build and debug manually when I am trying to learn something new.
How do you think about data privacy when building apps
I care deeply about user privacy. When designing any user-facing projects, I always add defenses against malicious users. A big challenge with Villio has been making sure user data remains private.
Have you worked with cloud platforms before
Yes, I've worked with GCP and Azure.
What's your experience with Postgres

I've used Postgres for several fullstack apps, including this one. I've also used Postgres with pgvector as a vector database for a RAG chatbot. It's pretty good and it has a lot of support in Python, I'd say.
What's the most useful thing you've learned from hackathons

The most important thing I've learned from hackathons is to not fear putting yourself out there. Everything from networking, pitching your project, and making new friends requires you to have faith in yourself and to not be scared to share who you are with other people. Sometimes it doesn't work out, but it's always worth doing. I've met a lot of friends that way !
Do you enjoy teaching or mentoring others

I do, to an extent. Back in high school I was math tutor for children from kindergarten to high school. I like guiding people to answers instead of giving them straight out. I try to be careful not to take the puzzle and problem-solving away. Sometimes it's tedious and frustrating to not get a straight answer, but it gives people the space to grow by themselves.
What's your proudest accomplishment so far

My proudest accomplishment is Hack404! It was so amazing to plan an entire 200+ person hackathon in under 4 months and seeing it come to life in-person. I can't stress how grateful I am for everyone who made it happen.
What do you like to do when you're not coding
I like making music, making matcha, and spending time with friends.
How do you personally define being “ready” for growth and chaos in a work environment?

Being "ready" to me means having humility, being open to learn, and overall ready to accept whatever opportunities and setbacks come my way. Be ready to make the most of the environment you're in and the mental collectedness to reflect on your mistakes and what to do next.
